Award.AwardTitle: Future Faculty Workshop: Grooming Diverse Leaders for the Future, Summers of 2016-2018
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: A major challenge to American technological and societal advancement is to effectively harness our diverse talent and human resources in science and engineering. Without developing a future generation of talented individuals from a range of social, economic, and racial backgrounds and genders, the United States will become less technologically competitive. Despite the numerous activities that attempt to address this issue, the continued and disproportionally low engagement of underrepresented groups remains a major hurdle. In this project, a series of two-day Future Faculty Workshops (FFWs) have been created to better enable underrepresented scientists (minorities, women, persons with disabilities, first-generation college students, etc.) to compete for, and obtain, faculty positions in areas related to Chemistry, Chemical Engineering, Materials Science and Engineering, Biomaterials, Polymer Science and Soft Materials Physics. The FFW is tackling two factors that are key to adding academic diversity. First, the FFW is designed to provide information and intellectual content to reduce the knowledge gap and improve confidence in the journey toward professorship in an active-learning and highly-engaging workshop environment. Second, sustainable and highly productive mentor-mentee and mentee-mentee networks are formed by pairing students/postdoctoral associates with active and invested research mentors to develop career-long relationships. The outcome-based FFW framework, as well as the detailed assessment protocols and metrics, are expected to serve as a blueprint for subsequent efforts and best practices in all areas of science and engineering. As a long-term benefit, the act of increasing the proportion of underrepresented groups in the science and engineering academic realm is one of the most transformational and effective mechanisms for enhancing overall diversity in the future science and engineering workforce.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: Three two-day Future Faculty Workshops (one each summer) are designed to mentor a diverse cadre of senior graduate students and postdoctoral researchers with an interest in materials science and engineering, specifically soft materials and biomaterials. A key goal of the workshops is to better enable underrepresented scientists (minorities, women, first-generation college students, persons with disabilities, etc.) to compete for, and obtain, assistant professor faculty positions in soft materials research. Additionally, the workshops are expected to serve as a blueprint for subsequent efforts in all areas of materials science and engineering. This effort is necessary because increasing the proportion of underrepresented groups in the science and engineering academic realm is one of the most effective mechanisms for enhancing overall diversity in the future science and engineering workforce. Thus, the workshops herein address several necessary aspects on the road toward assistant professorship, such as creating long-term and sustainable mentor networks, disseminating the "written" and "unwritten" rules of the professorship process, providing feedback on mentee proposed research topics, and instilling confidence in navigating the application process. Hosting approximately 45-50 mentees and 15-20 mentors per summer, the workshops provide the mentees with information on the path to academia through (i) significant discussion-based interactions describing the steps along the academic pathway, (ii) select faculty research lectures in emerging areas of interdisciplinary research, (iii) numerous networking sessions, and (iv) active-learning (student/postdoctoral associate-led) presentations and role-playing of application, interview, and workplace scenarios. A logic model platform, pre- and post-workshop surveys, longer-term follow-up questionnaires, and independent workshop observers add to the dynamic and adaptable framework of the workshops and permit detailed assessment and refinement during the 3-year period and beyond.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

A major challenge to American technological and societal advancement is our current inability to effectively harness the diverse talent and human resources in science and engineering. In this effort, we hosted a series of two-day Future Faculty Workshops (FFWs) to better enable underrepresented scientists (minorities, women, persons with disabilities, etc.) to compete for assistant professor positions in areas of soft materials (polymers) research. The specific focus of the FFW was related to the chemistry, physics, engineering, and biology of soft materials, and the workshops provided key information for subsequent efforts that can focus on all areas of materials science and engineering. The FFW addressed several necessary aspects on the road toward assistant professorship, including creating longterm and sustainable networks, disseminating the 'written' and 'unwritten' rules of the professorship process, providing feedback on mentee proposed research topics, and instilling confidence in navigating the application process. We demonstrated effectiveness through the number of participants who have secured academic positions (and are currently competitive for positions), the networks that have been established (mentee-mentee, mentor-mentee, and mentor-mentor), and the progression of several early FFW mentees to the associate professor level at their current institutions, through historical iterations of the workshop. Herein, we improved the FFW's impact and reach through the use of a dynamic logic model that permitted ready adaptation and assessment to inform best practices.  Furthermore, we expanded the highly-engaged group of quality FFW mentors that are pivotal to enhancing diversity in the professoriat.  Note: we were able to extend the grant for an extra year due to generous university support.

 

Intellectual Merit

The two-day FFWs focused on mentoring a diverse cadre of senior graduate students and postdoctoral researchers with an interest in materials science and engineering, specifically soft materials and biomaterials.  Hosting approximately 45-50 mentees and 20 mentors per summer, the FFW provided the mentees with information on the path to academia through (i) significant discussion-based interactions describing the steps along the academic pathway, (ii) select faculty research lectures in emerging areas of interdisciplinary research, (iii) numerous networking sessions, and (iv) student/postdoc-led presentations of research proposal topics. This combination of FFW activities was designed to provide information, promote intellectual development, enable the establishment of mentee-mentor and mentee-mentee networks, and improve mentee confidence associated with navigating the academic career path. An ancillary benefit of the FFW was interaction between the mentors, especially between senior faculty and junior faculty, which helped advance the careers of junior faculty. The program was evaluated in conjunction with an assessment consultant, using a logic model approach. Pre- and post-workshop surveys, longer-term follow-up questionnaires, and independent workshop observers permitted refinement of the FFW during the 4-year period and beyond.

 

Broader Impacts

A primary goal of the FFW was to help increase diversity in the academic pipeline by developing a program that targets researchers in groups that traditionally have been underrepresented in science and engineering. Without developing this future generation of talented individuals from a range of social, economic, and racial backgrounds and genders, the United States could become less technologically competitive. There are other programs that attempt to address this issue; however, the continued and disproportionally low engagement of underrepresented minorities remains a major hurdle. Herein, we tackled two factors that are key to adding academic diversity. First, we provided information and intellectual content to reduce the knowledge gap and improve confidence in the journey toward professorship. Second, we enabled the formation of sustainable and highly productive mentor-mentee and mentee-mentee networks by pairing students/postdocs with active and engaged research mentors to develop career-long relationships.  Increasing the proportion of underrepresented groups in the science and engineering academic realm is transformational and is one of the most effective mechanisms for enhancing overall diversity in the future science and engineering workforce.

 

Summary

Workshop mentors and mentees came from the departments of bioengineering, biomedical engineering, chemistry, chemical engineering, materials science, mechanical engineering, molecular engineering, physics, and neuroscience.  Mentors and mentees came from R1, PUI, and HBCU institutions. 

 

Over the course of the 4 years of workshops, greater than 96% of the mentee respondents agreed or strongly agreed that the workshop was worth their time and that after participation in the workshop, they have more confidence in navigating the academic application process. Mentees indicated that they particularly enjoyed the informal, interactive, smaller group setting in which mentors and mentees could have honest conversations that allowed for detailed information sharing and the formation of sustainable mentee-mentee and mentor-mentee relationships. Mentees mentioned that they will use the information gained in the workshop to help them cultivate mentor relationships in their field, prepare application materials, and build their research proposals.  Furthermore, longitudinal surveys clearly indicated that the mentees who chose to pursue (and secure) academic positions were able to draw upon worthwhile knowledge, confidence, and experience gained from the workshops.
